THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

s.w: Er, it's in the other magazine I fetched from work after the I'd left them at work.
That's the one I found out what mine was .
Look at black hair on that hooker!
Cos it's a completely new series with him innit?
Well he's never been on before.

pause.w: Big baby!

s.w: It must have been two month old.
Where did you ge get this from?
Er, whatsername bought it for her.
Albert will you stop pratting with that!
You're turning sound up and down like a yo-yo!

shift.w: The Ox is strong and reliable, a practical person with a head for business .

s.w: Cos you know he's sitting there!
She's, saw her in town today.
They walk from Bentley into town for all John's .

pause.w: You can try and put them

ptr.w: I thought it must have been .

s.w: She says they've got a student teacher, she's only about twenty three .

pause.w: I mean, where do you see at the beginning ?
Will you geroff my back!

unclear.w: lucky he's not feeling up it, he's feeling everything else!

s.w: He tried to grope up back of my thing!
He's in a playful mood i'n't he?

ptr.w: I bought a packet of these and he opened them, took one out, and put them back, and put them in his pocket.

s.w: And he said to me, I said, that's, do you want one June?
He's putting them back in his pocket, he don't ask anybody if they want any does he?
And he goes, I can't see you buying any!
I couldn't get over Des asking me if I wanted a bottle of beer!
I nearly passed out on floor!
Not very often you get owt off a businessman June.
Er, has he fetched you that letter yet ?
It's Des what's sorting it out.
Oh it were Julie's birthday yesterday and she didn't tell us.
She didn't tell us till today.
That's why she didn't tell you !
No, she must be thirty seven.

pause.w: Terry sent her a card and wrote on back, all my love Terry.

s.w: Can you lend me a fiver ?

pause.w: It's the thought what

ptr.w: He went and bought her a sherbet

s.w: What did Liz say to that?
I'm surprised erm people round corner didn't buy her a blinking blow up doll doll without the wedding tackle.
Well I'm not kidding you, you know when we went in fish shop last time we were there?
That Pakistani, or Indian, whatever he is, that's got a fish shop, he's bought, we were in there five minutes and before we came she knew his whole life history!
Was he living in flat by himself?
Did his mum and dad live round here?
Liz to this, to this, in the bought fish shop up there.
Cos they, when I went in that shop it's, he'd tell me he hadn't, he'd failed his driving test.
Oh that, to go to top of Broadway.

ptr.w: Been for my test today he say, and I failed.

pause.w: I says, what a what as, a shopkeeper?

shift.w: He says, no my driving test !

ptr.w: Well he come into garage the other day and told me his wife had kicked him out!

s.w: He told me his wife had kicked him out!

pause.w: I were killing myself with laughter!

ptr.w: Oh they got some funny ideas some of them!

s.w: These are not as hot as they usually are are they?
I thought they were right mild.

pause.w: I mean you used to be able to go ah!

s.w: He's toned them down a hell of a lot.
You're not supposed to eat more than four packets in twenty four hours.
That reminds me, I've got that box and all, the you know when you took that bo that box of Twix back that time what do you do when you take them back?
That square place where you don't
And do they take them off you?
They give you a, a credit note and you, you go put them back.
I fetched double Twix instead of single, you picked wrong ones up.
I said to you, are these right ones?
I said, yeah, and you picked them up and looked at dates and chucked them on cart.
And they won't sell will they not?
It were me that realized we'd fetched wrong ones, not Des.

pause.w: Did you get any money back when you took that box of crisps back that time?

s.w: No, he we, he was credited with it wasn't he?
How d'ya mean credited with it?
I wonder what he's done with that?

pause.w: We've got them Milky Ways to take back yet.

s.w: And then most of Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning.
I'm on Saturday afternoon and all day Sunday.
I might do this car Saturday morning.
That's the only time I'm gon na get to do it innit?
All depends if you're gonna leave it there while you do it.
You mean, while he's at work?

ptr.w: No I mean we ain't got much choice.

s.w: Unless he decides to go away and leave me again!
Does he pay you extra for doing car like?
Well they give me a tenner for hoovering it out.
I hope you're not taking my One-Step?
I've not done that car out for ages.
Yeah, but you haven't done mine.
Mind you, it's not cutting out now.

ptr.w: Good job you haven't got Liz's, hers broke down yesterday!

s.w: It's not cutting out at all now?
It stalls, I stalled it tonight but well I just caught it.
Don't get settled cos I have to go toilet.
You know, I told you that day Ju I saw Julie walking down top of Broadway?
They've just had it brought back from whatsername's? haven't they?
Well they got a Sierra she's on about a Fiat.
I were gon na say it, it's checking Fiats .

pause.w: Which Fiat?

ptr.w: She's got a , and she's got a Fiat.

pause.w: But her dad's got well Stu's dad's got a Sierra ain't he?

s.w: And Sierras are if something jerks it cuts the fuel line dun nit?
It stops it and you've got a button somewhere on your dash what you press to release it.
Well they didn't know and they to it were towing Julie's car and the tow belt snapped, and of course when it jerked this car forward it cut the petrol off.
And he couldn't get no petrol for it and he had to call A A out.
So she had to walk home and he walked home !
Not on, not when they're, when they're already in motion.
Set off with the towing Julie's car and the tow rope just snapped in two, and it jerked both cars and it cut off the fuel.
Well he should have just zoomed off!
It shouldn't have jerked his, should it?
Yeah, but you've got your feet down and you're towing summat, and then suddenly it releases, it just goes er forward a bit dunnit?
paper about that Robin Reliant and he's done it all up and it does hundred mile an hour!
I wouldn't fancy going down no bloody motorway, hundred eight in one of them!

ptr.w: I tell you some of them Robi

s.w: he had a Honda Civic engine in it!
I shouldn't think anybody'd insure it!
Then that bloody prat towing down motorway at hundred mile an hour!
And they're going hundred mile an hour!

pause.w: He had a new Fiat er what were it?

ptr.w: The next one up from ours.

s.w: He had a new Coroma two litre and he's towing this bloke on motorway at hundred mile an hour !
Well Terry came down last night.

ptr.w: Will you have any exams this year?

s.w: I've got I've got one in March for definite.
I think I've got one in April.
You don't pay for them though do you?
I have one in April two in May
And what are they all on like?

ptr.w: three in June or two in June and then when we go back we've got about three in September

s.w: and we'll have some more at Christmas.
They're not mock exams are they?
I've got my Red Cross in stage one, my R S A part one and two, stage two.
I've got shorthand Pitman not Pitman, R S A, shorthand Teeline shorthand Teeline again at end of one, end of year.
And I've got another one in word processing, hopefully.
My audio o transcription medical and I've got my Teeline medical.
And then after that I've got er that thing in for my exams.
None of them, there's only two of them that are to do with my diploma.

pause.w: All the rest are at fortunately.

s.w: How long will you finish this?
Middle of next year or end of next year?
It'll be July when we take the exams.
That's when the course will actually finish.
But I don't know how long it is before I get my results back.
But you can get a post as a medical secretary in a hospital or a G P without having your full diploma.
If yous let it, cos to get the full diploma you've got to get your two skills which is medical audio, and medical shorthand, you've got to have them two skills to get the diploma.
And you've also got four papers ethics and etiquette you got an English one, a medical aspects one, and a clerical skills one.
Not a clerical skills one, but, office procedures.
And you've got to pass all them, plus your two skills to get the diploma.
But you can resit any what you fail the following year.
Teresa says, the only one what presents any difficulty is usually the medical aspects one.
Well why should that present anything different?
Because it covers such a wide area.
It says the English paper you only need, you only need seventy five percent for your erm it's seventy five percent pass rate.
You've got to get above seventy five to pass.

ptr.w: That's quite high that, you know, seventy five percent!

s.w: Well it's got to be ain't it?
The office procedures, she said, is simple anyway, and yet, ethics and etiquette is a, she said, and your teacher works you that hard and it just drills in anyway!
No, but, seventy five percent is a high pass rate.

ptr.w: Well I don't know who she is that sends letters out to your nana, but she's bloody useless!

s.w: She misses more words out than she gets in!
And she just writes over them in, in pen!
If it's her computer though, they might just erm, thingy it and change it to suit them.
Well it wouldn't be on word processor.
Cos it's, the you're supposed to that's what it's for so you can check all your spellings.

ptr.w: A lot of them letters that come out are already done and you just delete

s.w: Gonna say that's they're all on word processor that's what I'm saying.
I got a pass, oh I got a distinction for, we did er like mock exam for word processing, I got a pass.
her in, her the launderette were asking me er she was, she were on about I, ain't you got a job yet?
I said, I think I'm too qualified to get a job!
She said we she said, well aye, you might be.
She says, i' n't your daughter i er a nice girl?
She says what's sh what's she do?
I said, oh she's at college.
I says, she says er what she's studying?
I said, well she's er she's going in for medical secretary.
She said, well where does she get her brains from?
I sa I said well who do you think?
I says, I'm overqualified for work, I says, and it looks like she's gonna end up that way if you're not careful!
So she said, I think she's ever so pretty!
Said, pity her manners don't blink er mannerisms don't match her looks !
Teresa's on about erm a she were asking me if anybody'd be interested into going on to higher er education after this?
Yeah, but you get, you don't get no grant for that.

unclear.c: . But if it's only a part-time so you can actually work part-time that's the difference.

s.w: Fantastic salary if you get qualified!
It's alright if you can get day release from your
That's what you want to be after, day release.
They're trying to make our course into a three day a week.
Erm, nine till six at night.
you get we get a mental block after three three o'clock us !
I mean, doing shorthand for four hours a day, it's too much!
Well, just think, when you're working full-time you'd be working nine till five.
I know, but it's different when you're concentrating
on studying and when you're concentrating on working.

ptr.w: Billy, er Billy 's one of Billy 's daughter-in-laws, she, she does it part-time.

s.w: That's what erm that's which one of them, who were it telling me?
Er I don't know whether it were the young lad that comes in, or whether it was Jes that were telling me.
I can't imagine it being Jes.
I think it were Jes what were telling you .
Well it might have been Jes cos I don't know tha well they've got, I think they've got two children.
And she were doing it full-time and then she went she had children and then she went part-time.
But I don't think she's working.
That's one advantage of being medical secretary

ptr.w: I think she's just had another baby or summat.

s.w: cos if you get in a big organization like N H S, they provide a creche.
And thi I mean, you don't have to pay for the creche cos it comes in the, it's part of your

ptr.w: It's like nurses at hospital innit?

s.w: Well that's the creche what you get into.
That's why a lot of people will go into medical secretary who have children.
Has Sue got a job at all?
I think she'll be married shortly.
I can see her marrying him.
But he's one of them lads where she'll never have owt, cos he don't do, he won't bloody work will he?
Well I'm gon na report him!

ptr.w: And he, he's getting one parent benefit!

pause.w: He'll be getting all sorts for that young girl!

s.w: As soon as he gets a house she will leave home.
He's not so sure of that.
Have they had an argument like?

pause.w: She's got two men.

s.w: I know, but always nice to know.
Bit of scandal now and again.
You're getting worse than a woman you, now you're at home!
I know, there's nowt from men though is there?
They say women are bitchy but have you ever heard a conversation betwe

ptr.w: That back door wants rubbing down I think don't it, before you paint it dunn it?

pause.w: Yeah

s.w: I were just thinking where my sander were.
Did you clean that cupboard out I asked you to do?
That one where oil's kept cos it I, the last time, I cleaned it out last time and put a some kitchen roll in in a plastic bag on top but it's all over again.
Have you see how that unit's all cracked under sink?
I can't understand why it's cracked like that.
I, you don't know why it's cracked?

ptr.w: That one where we used to keep rubbish bin.

vocal.w: I cracked it when I put it in.

pause.w: I knelt on it if you remember.
And broke it.

s.w: I can't get over that ruddy idiot in !
Moving all that stuff into, a washer, a cooker, in middle of floor like that!

ptr.w: It don't matter if they were .

s.w: I think they're too alike but after saying that, they're quite nice and he made such a bugger of them ain't he?

ptr.w: Put them in the wrong places ain't he?

s.w: I mean what he's do I, I know why he's done it.
They didn't what he's done, he's thought well I'll just do that and incorporate the sink in it.
Yeah, but fancy putting sink up in corner like that!
They can't put a worktop along that wall under window cos it cuts the unit off.
If it'd been me and I were gonna put it there, I would have put a window there to look out of.
Well I can't understand why he wanted to move the sink from where it were!
I think it was in a lovely position.

ptr.w: They could have had cupboards right round there, rate along there if they'd left

pause.w: You say worse words!
Ah.

s.w: One of lasses are getting married, at college is getting married in July.
Always say we got married in registry office.
What's that gotta do with owt?
Have you seen that picture of my nana?
Our Margaret says our my mam lo I look like my mam looks there.
Do you know yo a we where the hell did your Margaret look?

ptr.w: I think that Aunty Margaret looks more like her.

s.w: I were gon na say, yo yo she looks more like your mam than any of them.
Cos on that photo, my nan's got a right sort of face hasn't she?
Cos Aunty Margaret used didn't she?
Your Aunty Margaret's thinner now than when she got married.

pause.w: Ooh!

s.w: I can't cough and I can't move.
I can't afford to have any more time off.
You're not having any more time off, I've made my mind up!
Jes said, I thought you'd have been off rest of week.
You know, you can't weigh him up.
I gets on telephone, I says June's not coming into work today .
I thought you'd told him I were having a couple of days
I didn't realize you'd o you hadn't said that I'd be off a couple
Jes said, I can't let June come to work today.
That's right, she's in bed poorly.
After I'd been talking to him about leaving.
He says that's a when, he said I can't let June come to work he said I was he said first things that went through my mind were someone's decided to finish, what's gone off?
I told him you were poorly.

ptr.w: Well it was, he had to go to er Heldon yesterday.

s.w: He said Dawn rang up er, oh!
He said Dawn was swimming on a Tuesday he says, but because you hadn't rang up, he said, I thought oh, she must be coming to work.
So he said, our Dawn rang up and said I wonder if she did my shift on Monday.
Er he'd, and she said er she says to him what you doing today?
He says well June must be coming in cos she hadn't rang up.
She says, oh well I'm going swimming then.
He said, well I, I, I won't need you anyway.
He said, then half an hour after Albert rung up to say that you weren't coming to work, so I were right in shit!
For some reason Jes was out there, why can't he get Jes to do it.
Well he and Jes were doing summat.
Oh he were washing windows other day.
He had to, i th he was up on ladders and they were washing o you know sign up on top?
He cle he scrubbed all that!
Must have been about Monday, or Tuesday.
Well the Jehovah's Witnesses come in last week before I come off work, must have been Thursday, they said you haven't seen window cleaner lately have you?
I says, I had to clean them myself last time.
He said, I'll get onto them and I'll tell him he has to come and clean your windows he's been a bit busy.
I don't think he'd been for about six month.
No, well it's not that long.
Look at this bugger, eating Victory V's!
He'll eat shit on bloody shovel if you give it him!
Them menthol ones you bo you bought me, God, they were burning my throat!
And my throat were on fire!
Cos it hit bottom of cage.
Well I took it out, a load of it out this morning in my hand cos he were nearly sitting on it!

pause.w: Like , they gotta haven't they?

s.w: I said to Jes he, the only bird I know that can shit through side of a bloody cage bars and, and get it through!
He says, I know, Carmen used to go crackers that's why she went and fetch him here.
I know, you'll have a carpet have to do it, do that again.

pause.w: Put you on your chain and take you out!
You bugger!

ptr.w: I can't see how that chain fits on him!

s.w: How does he put it on him.
He he lifts it through and pulls it till it goes on his leg.

pause.w: What you doing you bald headed bugger!

s.w: He, he can't see that a dog!

pause.w: You daft buggers!

s.w: Are you gonna sort her out Barney?

unclear.w: keep trying to reach that picture.

s.w: Have you seen mess on that floor in back of that, in office?
All bloody mud and stuff they've got all over it!
Mind you, somebody had cleaned all toilet out, I don't know who.
Or sink, cos sink were clean, and toilet
Well I put bleach down it on Saturday.
I bet whoever did toilet out used
There weren't a lot of bleach in it.
I was actually gonna open it put some bleach round the edge.

ptr.w: Well somebody had cleaned all sink cos sink were there weren't a mark on sink when I went today.

s.w: Dawn must have done it then.
But all the wash cloths had gone.
Well I washed out what was in the toilet again on Sunday.
It's a waste of time cos they just splatter it all back up again!
but I forgot to take my typewriter hadn't I?
Got all this stuff to type up and I'd forgotten my typewriter.
You should put a notice up, if you make the mess, clean it up!
They'd bloody take notice down and push it down toilet!

ptr.w: Well they wi I'll tell you now

s.w: if I worked there and they didn't do it, I'd just turn round and say, no you're not having the bloody key until you can learn to keep it clean.
It's not so bad now because tap's working again.
They're not washing in like they were before.
I just bi I went outside, I mean, I was gonna go outside five minutes before and not notice anything, and I went out five minutes later and I heard this water running.
And I looked up at tap and this water were pouring out of tap, I thought oh!
I went to turn tap off cos that's what I thought it were.
And it were coming down to tap.
So I got out the car and I went over and I, turned it down, as it were turning down I saw it wasn't pouring just out the tap, it was also pouring from the

ptr.w: I don't know who fixed it.

s.w: He said he were gonna get in touch with somebody.
Then this bloke came in how long's your tap
I says, I don't know I've just rung him about it.
As if we have enough droughts without we it, people like

ptr.w: You should have said, the tap's nowt to do with us it belongs to him that has the garage!

s.w: If I had my own way, I shall tell him where to shove his petrol!
I don't know who he were!
Got nowt to do with him how much water you use at the garage, it's pa you should turn round and ta

ptr.w: Yeah, but it was pouring all over the forecourt.

pause.w: You should have told him that we pay for it by the gallon not by the year!

s.w: It's nowt to do with you!
You get some funny buggers coming to garages you know!
My wo is that one at garage?
I mean, with frost and whatsername we've had just lately they can expect bust pipes anywhere where they're where they're not protected.
Did you see that top of Broadway?
Been like that a couple of days.
Yeah I know, but it weren't that , now it's got it all wheels to top.

ptr.w: You don't go down a hill.

s.w: And you don't go down, up the hill.
Go up hill that way then.
It's down hill all the way.

ptr.w: Well it's only that little bit of rise there.

pause.w: Not like going up there.

s.w: Did I tell you Chris's wife were pregnant?
Claire made it on the Sunday, I said innit about time you took your wife out?
I says, oh, she were right depressed when she came in.
I says, she wanted to go out Saturday and you'd gone to work.

pause.w: Cos me and my brother had been working on wagon again.

s.w: And with it being a nice day.
He says, I feel awful we were making plans that being the week to go out so they had trouble with wagon so we had to spend some time on wagon.

shift.w: And he says, it weren't bad enough me not going out that day, but with it being nice weather and all.

s.w: It can't, ho he can't hook it.
We'll have to learn you George.

event.w: Have you seen her hair yet?

s.w: she's had it cut into bob and permed.
She's had it cut short then?
Well it er, about that long, about my length weren't it?
Cos she always used to have it in a pony tail.
She had it cut to there and permed.
I, I can't remember if she's had it done straight or not.
Cos underneath it, I mean it didn't look nice but when she lifted it up it's how mine was, like it is now, flat underneath.
It's gone like that straight away.
She said, well if it's like this after one night, what's it gon na look like when I wash it?
So, sh I mean, it cost her thirty five pounds!
And there were fiver off it.
I tell you summat, I'd a, go back!
I remember Kerry, quite a few years going to er to
in town and it cost her twenty quid!

ptr.w: And that's a few years ago.

pause.w: you know, his ordinary name's

s.w: I remember once me and your Aunty June going have our hair done there and when we come out it was snowing!
And it cost us a bomb!

ptr.w: She paid thirty five pounds for a perm, and she got a fiver, she'd got a coupon for a fiver off.

s.w: Lee's er paid for Liz to go and have her nails manicured tomorrow.
Cos, er, that Angeliques at Thorne.
you know where that whatsername is?
Er er, Fox that barb er that hairdressers
when we, ma when my mum had been married twenty five years that time.
Well, she she waxes Lee's legs but she goes
she goes to part-time so they get it at a reduced rate.
Just about Epilady, but I couldn't stand them waxed!

pause.w: You think you can't neither!

s.w: At least with Epilady you take a rest if

ptr.w: Have you seen that new technique they have with honey and warm thingy?
Yeah I no it don't hurt.

s.w: I'm just wondering what waxing does though.
The only time it hurts is when it nips your skin!
out now and it's like erm it's like tre er, it's like soft toffee.
And they roll it over like that

But it were so quick it were untrue!
That's how they were doing it.

unclear.w: that electrolysis, that's the best way but it takes ages.

s.w: got to keep your feet up for so long before

ptr.w: What with all the advertisements on, bloody

s.w: They do have them on now and again.
They have them on a lot now.

pause.w: What a waste of a good car!

s.w: They'll have a parachute on it I expect.
Yeah, but you do for a programme.

ptr.w: Can't see no bloody parachute on there!
I think it'll be a cardboard unit.

pause.w: I suppose they could do it, yeah.

s.w: I did a lot of revision on my spellings yester for a spelling test, Claire didn't turn up.
We had a medical aspects test.

ptr.w: She don't half have some time off them bloody, that teaching staff!
So we had an extra hour for dinner.

s.w: So we had a walk round town.
